Cultural Context: Tikanga Considerations

This lesson integrates MÄtauranga MÄori (MÄori knowledge) with climate science. Key concepts include:

  • Whakapapa: The interconnected genealogy of all living things
  • Kaitiakitanga: Guardianship and sustainable management of resources
  • Mauri: The life force present in all things
  • Taonga: Treasured species and resources

Cultural protocols to observe:

  • Begin with a karakia (prayer) to acknowledge the whenua (land)
  • Respect tapu (sacred) concepts when discussing environmental changes
  • Use correct MÄori pronunciation (audio resources provided)
  • Consult local iwi for region-specific knowledge where possible

Understanding Climate Change Through Dual Lenses

Compare Perspectives Activity

Complete the table below comparing Western science and MÄtauranga MÄori perspectives:

Climate Aspect Western Science View MÄtauranga MÄori View
Causes of climate change
Impact on oceans
Seasonal changes
Solutions/approaches

Case Study: Tuna (Eels) and Climate Change

Research how climate change affects tuna (freshwater eels), a taonga species:

  1. How does warming water affect tuna migration patterns?
  2. What traditional knowledge exists about tuna life cycles?
  3. How might kaitiakitanga practices help protect tuna?

Present your findings as either:

Assessment Rubric

Criteria Achieved Merit Excellence
Understanding of climate science Basic description of climate change Clear explanation with some examples Detailed analysis with multiple examples
Integration of MÄtauranga MÄori Mentions MÄori concepts Explains connections to MÄori worldviews Deep synthesis of knowledge systems
Critical thinking Simple comparisons Analyzes similarities/differences Evaluates strengths of each approach
Practical applications Identifies basic solutions Proposes relevant strategies Develops innovative, culturally-grounded approaches

Self-Checklist

I have considered both scientific and MÄori perspectives
I have used MÄori terms correctly
I have shown how systems are interconnected
I have proposed practical solutions

Extension Activities

1. Local Climate Impacts Research

Investigate how climate change is affecting your local area through both scientific data and kÅrero tuku iho (oral histories). Interview elders about observed environmental changes.

2. Maramataka (MÄori Lunar Calendar) Project

Compare traditional seasonal knowledge with modern climate data. Create a digital or physical display showing how maramataka indicators are changing.

3. Kaitiakitanga Action Plan

Develop a school or community climate action plan incorporating both scientific and MÄori approaches to sustainability.

Teacher Implementation Notes

Prior Knowledge

Students should have basic understanding of:

  • Climate change causes and effects
  • MÄori concepts of whanaungatanga and kaitiakitanga
  • Local ecosystems

Differentiation Strategies

  • Support: Provide pre-filled portions of comparison table, word banks
  • Extension: Have students research specific iwi climate adaptation plans

Timing

  • Introduction: 1 period
  • Main activities: 2-3 periods
  • Assessment: 1-2 periods

Cross-Curricular Links

  • Social Studies: Treaty of Waitangi and resource management
  • English: Persuasive writing about climate action
  • Geography: Local environmental changes

Resources and References

  • "Kaitiakitanga: MÄori Perspectives on Conservation" - Harmsworth & Awatere

Audio-Visual Resources

  • Te Papa: Matariki and Environmental Knowledge
  • MÄori Television: Te Taiao documentary series
  • RNZ: "MÄori Knowledge and Climate Science" podcast series
